awd_titl_txt: RUI: Measurement of DNA Thermal Denaturation (Tm) on Surfaces to Quantify the Effects of Surface Interactions on the Stability of Hybridized DNA Structures
awd_abstract_narration:
In this award, funded by the Chemical Measurement and Imaging Program of the Division of Chemistry, Professor Aric Opdahl of the University of Wisconsin - La Crosse and his undergraduate student researchers will be supported to investigate the thermal denaturation of DNA on surfaces using a variety of analytical methods, including surface Plasmon-enhanced fluorescence imaging, atomic force microscopy, and other methods.  The work aims to elucidate how the stability of DNA changes upon binding to surfaces.

Besides being important as the carrier of genetic information in many higher organisms, DNA is increasingly being used in nanotechnology, medical diagnostics, and other unexpected areas of technology.  Many of the newer applications of DNA in technology require the immobilization of DNA onto solid surfaces or other structures.  The binding of DNA to surfaces causes changes in its properties that are still poorly understood, it is the aim of research like that of Prof. Opdahl and his students to learn much more about the ways in which the properties of DNA change upon binding.  Besides the broader scientific impact of this research, the undergraduate research students participating in this research will be exposed to cutting-edge research in analytical chemistry with a talented researcher and educator.  The research program also includes an international collaboration with the International Iberian National Laboratory, which will broaden the horizons of the young people working with Prof. Opdahl on this research.

por.por_cntn:
The project had two major scientific goals. The first goal was to develop new analytical instrumentation and methods for monitoring, over a wide range of temperatures, the responses from surface-based biosensors. Measuring sensor response at multiple temperatures is important, because the information can provide a more complete picture of sensor binding interactions, in particular how strongly an analyte binds to a probe fixed to the sensor surface. This type of information is of potential value, for example, for fundamental biomolecular/life science studies, for developing new pharmaceuticals, and for sensor optimization studies. The second goal was to apply those temperature dependent methods to a detailed study of the binding interactions of DNA hybridization sensors – a type of sensor commonly used as a genetic diagnostic.  

Through the award, we developed a set of methods that provide efficient measurement of biosensor response over a large temperature range. The method is based on generating a spatial temperature gradient along one direction of a square surface plasmon resonance (SPR) sensor surface.  The temperature gradient allows simultaneous monitoring of sensor binding in different locations of the sensor, which because of the gradient, are at different temperatures. The method overcomes many of the traditional limitations of SPR, providing, providing a simple way to calibrate the temperature of the sensor at any location, a straightforward measure of sensor binding at each location, and a way to measure the temperature dependence of the binding kinetics.  

The viability of these methods was demonstrated, using DNA hybridization sensors as a model system. The technique was able to distinguish the hybridization state of different types of DNA structures by their relative stabilities in the different temperature regions of the gradient. The technique was also used to characterize how the organization of DNA capture probes on the sensor surface affects their ability to recognize and bind with complementary DNA analytes in a contacting solution. One example of a parameter that was found to have a significant impact on sensor binding strength was the space between adjacent probe molecules on the sensor.  The combined results improve our fundamental understanding of DNA hybridization sensors, in particular aiding in the development of mathematical models that can be used to predict the stability of different DNA structures in sensor environments.

All aspects of this project were completed in a collaborative environment with University of Wisconsin-La Crosse (UW-L) undergraduates. The experiences provided through the project provided each student with valuable opportunity for development as they as they begin careers in the sciences.
